reasoning: The critique targets a moderately central support for the essay’s conclusion: the Section 3 move from “easygoing bounded views have serious problems” to “easygoingness is unlikely, so fussiness/no-easy-eutopia is likely.” If that inference were undermined, the essay’s technical case for fussiness would be substantially weakened, but not totally: Section 2’s fragility/product-of-factors argument and the broader claim that many plausible views are fussy could still stand without relying on intertheoretic normalization pathologies. Strength is moderate: it’s a plausible meta-level “your machinery is generating the weirdness” objection, and it correctly notes that vNM completeness/cardinality plus cosmic tails can yield dominance/fanaticism/pro-extinction pressures; however it doesn’t directly show that the essay’s fussiness results are artifacts rather than robust across alternative (still decision-guiding) formalisms, nor does it engage the many object-level reasons the essay gives for fussiness (multiplicative fragility, linear resource-separability, fat-tailed value-efficiency). Correctness is fairly high but not perfect: it somewhat overstates that the authors ‘use those pathologies to discredit the easygoing slice’—the essay also argues easygoing views are rare/implausible for independent reasons, and it explicitly flags intertheoretic comparisons as thorny rather than settled. The critique is clear and focused, with little dead weight, and largely constitutes one coherent “boomerang/meta-model” objection.
title: Pro-extinction pathologies may indict the modeling framework rather than easygoing views
